pros: Great people and work environment
cons: Low pay compared to competitors

job_title: Network Technician IV in Orono, ME
pros: Work-life balance Decent pay Hours available
cons: Little Training Slow lack of connection with management

review_title: Good people and mission, often confusing organization, excellent benefits
pros: Excellent benefits (thanks to strong union). Most people great to work with and supportive. Lovely campus, dedicated students.
cons: Lack of or difficult coordination between departments and units. Shifting organizational structure in upper-level administration.

job_title: Project Manager II in Orono, ME
pros: Work life balance is good
cons: Work load can be excessive

pros: Plenty of professionals who are willing to assist you in learning and growing. Allows hybrid/remote work at times which keeps it flexible.
cons: Can be stressful to meet deadlines.

job_title: Assistant Director of Advising in Portland, ME
pros: Fulfilling work with students on campus
cons: Typically low salaries in higher education

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Orono, ME
pros: Pay for your tuition as well as this salary. Get to work at the ASCC
cons: Perhaps not the best educational system out there

job_title: Health Policy Analyst II in Portland, ME
pros: Collaborative team environment if on projects with astute principal investigator. Under this scenario, the work may be very demanding at times, but a rewarding and worthwhile experience. Excellent benefits package.
cons: If you on a project with a principal investigator that is too overextended, lacks management skills, or insecure the work environment can be frustrating as they are not focused on the current projects or do not know how to cultivate their team to excel. The opposite is true if the principal investigator is skilled in their role.

pros: Everyone is professional and kind. The benefits are great.
cons: I wish I had started sooner.

job_title: Classroom and Desktop Support in Orono, ME
pros: Great benefits and time off
cons: Salary is systematically structured, they struggle to pay people according to performance.

pros: Healthcare benefits, the people, the students
cons: The healthcare benefits help make up for the lower salary.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Bangor, ME
pros: Flexible work schedule and intellectual freedom
cons: Extreme winter, less diversity in the area

job_title: IT Specialist CL3 in Orono, ME
pros: Benefits, tuition reimbursement, flexible schedule
cons: Pay is lower than average

pros: good pay and benefits for the area
cons: bureaucratic, ineffectual and low energy place

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Portland, ME
pros: Culture, mission, commitment to equity, professional development and learning opportunities
cons: Under resourced, limited funding, parking

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Orono, ME
pros: Some professors are great to TA with.
cons: As you’d expect they pay minimum wage but it helps reduce the cost of school.

pros: you have your freedom with creating

job_title: Senior HRIS Analyst in Bangor, ME
pros:
Great benefits package
2 free classes a semester
Remote work is an option for qualified jobs

Pay is not highly competitive
Career advancement is limited
Turnover has become very high in recent years

pros: Maine is beautiful. Benefits are great. People are really nice and warm. Great place to retire.
cons: Payment too low, probably statewide for any jobs compared with most other states.

review_title: Good benefits good place to work
job_title: Associate Project Manager in Orono, ME
pros:
Benefit packages are amazing
Coworkers are great
Learning experiences are great
cons:
Pay isn't the greatest 
Communication can be hard

pros: friendly staff, welcoming environment, all around great to work for!
cons: I can think of no cons

pros: You get paid to pay your tuition.
cons: I must enter 5 words for Cons.

review_title: Great starter job for undergraduate students at Umaine
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Industry connections are made depending on the project worked on. You can develop real world experience, and keep up to date on what is coming next for that industry.
cons: The pay could be better, but it is connected to the university so there isn't much room there.

pros: Good benefits and work-life balance
cons: N/A - everything else is okay

review_title: Great Staff but Management is disorganized
pros: Great staff and co workers
cons: Low pay, management too disorganized and overbearing in some departments.

pros: Great selection of Professors, who are eager to help you if necessary.
cons: I don’t have any cons.

review_title: Good employer for work life balance
pros: Mission, culture, benefits, and professional development opportunities.
cons: salary, slow to change, legacy systems

pros: beautiful campus, nice and friendly coworkers
cons: No cons besides the colder weater in the winter months.

job_title: Financial Wellbeing Coach in Farmington, ME
pros: The staff was so supportive and friendly!
cons: Community can be too small for activity sometimes and programming can get difficult.

pros: Variety of tasks, emerging adult clientele
cons: Difficult to support family on salary

pros: Flexible, good pay, good benefits
cons: Located far away from civilization

review_title: money enough to survive on, environment horrible
pros: They offer free dental insurance (it helps but doesnt pay much) and discounted eye insurance. You can also have inexpensive health insurance if you are willing to have a "life coach" talk to you monthly and are willing to submit blood work yearly. If not, the insurance is unaffordable. The union does at least help with cost of living pay raises, which otherwise would be non existent for hourly employees.
cons: Working environment is abusive at best. Filling a travel mug with plain water is considered stealing. and one is forced to watch endless videos on how to maintain a positive attitude at work. You can ask for a day off weeks or months in advance because of a family reunion or wedding or such, but don't think you will actually get it off, not even if a coworker is willing to swap days with you.

review_title: wouldnt let a dog work here
pros: decent pay for the area. decent, but not great.
cons: Employees are treated very poorly. I had worked there a number of years, never called in sick. Got injured at work one day, asked to go to emergency and was told "no" Later in the day the pain was so bad I went anyway. Emergency sent me to the hospital. Being the diligent worker I was, I called and informed my supervisor while enroute to the hospital. I spent 5 hrs at the hospital and almost lost sight in my eye due to the delay in receiving treatment. I called upon being released from the hospital and was told, despite the doctors orders, that I should come into work anyway. They finally backed down when I said I had specific written instructions that I was absolutely not to do anything for 24 hrs. Even after submitting proper paperwork from the emergency room and the hospital I was accused of lying and had to sue for my workmans comp.  And I have seen other employees be treated worse than myself. It is a very corrupt place.

review_title: Good organization, bit too much red-tape
pros: Most of the people who work in the system are genuinely very friendly, relatable people. Usually everyone is interesting and happy to help, and tries very hard to do their job well and to offer good service. When it comes to helping the students, everyone seems fully committed to providing as much help as is reasonable.
cons: Some of the hiring and staffing practices are inadequate, and people can be given positions where there is nothing to do - meanwhile, other parts of the university are in desperate need of staffing. All of the bureaucracy makes the organization very top-heavy and difficult to coordinate, so things are slow to happen, and often confusing. This can be frustrating.

review_title: Exactly the kind of college job you expect
pros: It's an easy college job that you can use to do your homework. That's really about all it is--if you can dodge the issues.
cons:
Management is somewhat haphazard, because of the way orders come from outside the IT Support department. It's not entirely the ITSS management's fault, but they don't make it any easier.

You will not advance unless you suck up to the bosses a _lot_. Many broken promises re: advancement and wages.

pros: You get to work closely with professors, owing to the small size of the student body. This allows you to leverage their knowledge and insight better both in terms of subject matter and career goals.
cons: I worked in the dining halls and as a research assistant as well, and in all three positions I experienced a lot of mixed messages and miscommunications from my supervisors. At one point, myself and other research assistants were taken off the system payroll and put on our professor's grant money, which was a rocky and bizarre transition that wound up making someone quit.

pros: Lots of good people to work with who are passionate about their work.
cons: Low pay, increasingly bloated administration in the system, increasing social distance between those who work on the educational mission and those who are making decisions about resources.  Used to be a great place to work--worth the below average pay--but increasingly less so as the central administration takes increasing control over matters that are not in their areas of expertise.

job_title: Assistant Director of Student Financial Aid in Orono, ME
pros: Great benefits, one of the largest employers in the state, security, working with various and diverse population, most have security of a union.
cons: Promotion from within is almost impossible. Senior management sometimes has interesting directives which trickle down to lower levels. Firing people is nearly impossible with the unions, so some employees that should have been thrown out years ago keep hanging on to their jobs.

review_title: Get paid (little) to go to school with easy hours
pros: As a graduate student you can set your own pace to work at. You are getting paid to get an advanced degree which will make you wealthy someday.
cons: as a graduate student you are going to not make very much money and you will never get a raise. Theres always the constant threat of losing your funding or the fellowship running out. Professors want you to work for them forever and never graduate.

review_title: u of maine orono is laying off jobs like crazy
pros: Pay is above min wage
cons: Hourly employees treated badly by management. It is considered stealing to fill your coffee mug with coffee being thrown out at end of night. Employee assistance program all laid off, replaced with unhelpful cigna phone call. You are not allowed to wish anyone a merry christmas, happy kwanza or even hang candy canes. The new administration is cutting jobs to save money, but giving themselves raises. Benefits used to be good. But now you have to submit blood work to the university and have a wellness life coach in order to be able to afford the health insurance. As an employee, you have to pay to park your car on campus.

review_title: Was a good place to work.  Steadily declining.
pros: Benefits, classes are free, free access to Rec Center/Gym.
cons:
A dank and dreary subway stop on the railroad to success.  More and more of a corporation setting and attitude rather than academia.
No 'new-blood' in the system.  Department heads that have held the same seat for millennia are highly resistant to change, resulting in a stagnant and bureaucratic workplace.
Come here if you want a notch on your resume and move on after a year or two like everyone else (if it lasts that long).

review_title: Great student job if you're willing to work
job_title: Student Technical Assistant (Ice Rink) in Orono, ME
pros: It is a very relaxed working environment. Whenever there is downtime you can study for classes or get some homework done. If you work hard, you will be rewarded.
cons: There were some very late nights after hockey games that weren't fun, especially on school nights. Also, management didn't really do anything to weed out or reprimand lazy or unmotivated workers.

pros: I get to opportunity to work alongside with faculty and observe multiple classes in the Business department at the University of Maine.
cons: The pay is not good. The office that I work in is being reconstructed so there is certainly the tension of getting used to the new order. I realize that reconstructing an organization can be quite tricky but still I think this process can be handled in a much better way.

review_title: Great organization with hands off governance style.
pros: Loved the people, beautiful setting, great opportunities for recent grads to stay on as employees. Employees are competent and seek to build true connections with the student body. Never felt like a number or a lesser, was welcomed as a member of the team from the start.
cons: Strong disconnect between the college and the local town. Easy to forget that the beautiful campus is surrounded by area that is economically impoverished.

pros: I worked with intelligent, motivated, positive out-of-the box type people who were also rigorous academics.  My principal investigator led me to new lines of research I never would have considered.
cons: The system they work for tries it's best to follow the rules and push you to do the same (almost no "out of the box" thinking in the higher levels of the organization.  They pay extremely little for excellent work.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Orono, ME
pros: Small classes, a lot of individual attention from professors/advisors. There are decent research opportunities available. Grad stipends are typically enough to get by on, and depending on the program, you might get paid more, especially for PhDs. The location is great if you like the outdoors.
cons: The health insurance is terrible for graduate students and is far too expensive. Grad students are expected to work very hard and work much more than the required 20 hours. There are fewer courses offered than at bigger universities.

review_title: It was a lot of good research experience in the animal health lab.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Orono, ME
pros: Well you get a lot of experience going on with animal health aspects and also basic laboratory and research skills. Makes you think a reasonable and solid research approach.
cons: Initially Englishn as an international was challenging. It is hard to live in a place where it is hard to find your food taste you need in lower expenses. I needed work when I was there, I was staying idle when I was not doing research activity. That was troubling.

review_title: Research Assistant for the Department of Mechanical Engineering
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Orono, ME
pros: There is a lot of teacher student interaction since this is a smaller public University. Some of the Professors are very knowledgeable and great teachers if you work with the right ones.
cons: Being in Maine it is hard to get recognized outside of the state. Having a small budget makes it difficult to experience some things that other larger Universities may offer.

pros: It has its moments of being very rewarding, especially for student work. I am empowered to make decisions and I am learning real world skills both hard and soft.
cons: There are times when I am doing the random work that just needs to get done, which is often unfulfilling busy work.

review_title: Resident Assistant: a great learning and resume builing experience
pros: My community coordinator was really approachable and genuinely cared for me. All of the other RA's were excellent to collaborate with. This experience was a great opportunity to bulk up my CV, and I think it was one of the deciding factors that helped me get into pharmacy school.
cons: Calling the police for marijuana smells at 1am, but it happens on all campuses. Oh, and urine in the stairwells. Freshman dorms are unique.

pros: Many great people to work with. Good benefits.  Great location.  If you get in with the right group, you can be always learning on the job.
cons:
Your opportunities can vary greatly with what department you work in, some are great, some are terrible.
Currenty funding environment is terrible - which is bad for morale.

pros:
Can be fast past research in new inivative ideas.
Very flexible work schedule leaving you time to take classes.
Extremely friendly enviornment and co-workers
cons:
Parking is a joke. Along with Parking Services.
Little motivation to try hard, since metrics for measuring success don't exist.
Compensation is on the weak side.

pros: It really is dependent on what office you are working for. I work in Student Life and have a really great connection with all of my coworkers.
cons: The work can get really busy and sometimes it is hard to not work over your allotted 20 hours a week.

review_title: Great place to work, but unaffordable!
pros: My time at the University of Maine at Farmington was incredible -- wonderful colleagues, incredible students, and challenging work.
cons: The salary was abysmal and there are very few opportunities for advancement. Unions and administration don't care much about younger workers and have no incentive to find ways to recruit and retain talented young employees.

review_title: The system doesn't work as a real system
pros: The students I get to work with are incredible and are what motivate me to come to work everyday!
cons: The system does not work as a "system" and actually seems to encourage competition between already struggling campuses.

pros: Great atmosphere to work in. Consistent salary raises based on the number of years you have been working. Somewhat flexible hours, no work on the weekends. Access to the many dining areas on campus, plus health insurance through the campus health center. Days off when the university closes campus due to weather cancellations.
cons: Busy traffic on campus when the university is in session, can be hard to find parking at times.

pros: There are so many options for students that can help them to pay off their education and gain job experience.
cons: The breadth of opportunities can lead you down some unrewarding paths. Students should be cautious about where they choose to work on campus because you can be taken advantage of, but if you find the right work you can get very valuable experience where you are properly rewarded for your effort.

review_title: Peer Tutor — University of Maine Writing Center
job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Orono, ME
pros:
-Great atmosphere
-Amazing support from head of department
-Training program that doubles as a for-credit course
-Opportunity to go to conferences nationwide
-Only required to work 2 hours a week minimum, so can be balanced with a second job easily.
cons: You most certainly won't get rich working here, or even be able to live. However, it's a great resumé builder.

pros: Dynamic workplace that caterers to collaborative exploration. Half of the work done is research and development toward producing a product for a paying customer, and the other half is researching an area of interest.
cons: The lack of structure is different than other jobs. Weekly presentations on what you are currently working on. Low starting pay for a student employee.

pros: I love working for the University of Maine. I'm not contracted to work over the breaks, so it's great to have some time off while still getting paid.
cons: At least for graduate assistants, the first paycheck usually does not come until early October. However, the last paycheck comes in June, even after school/work has ended in May.

pros: Benefits were amazing. Work load was very reasonable, had the option to take up to two courses at the University per semester.
cons: Median age was over 35, was difficult to grow within department. There was some serious inner turmoil with the budget cuts and when the President  at Orono resigned before his contract ended.

review_title: It is ok, prefer big city
pros:
quiet and nice people, state college.
the campus is very beautiful.
it is a nice place to stay with child
cons:
small city, it is not convinent for traveling.
there are limited chance for other works nearby.
prefer to other big cities

review_title: Not great if you're looking for media work
pros: Flexible hours, bosses are usually understanding when you can't make it to work because you have to study
cons: Pay is awful, media jobs are boring, and there's no stepping stones from media at UMaine to a job in the creative field unless you take the initiative to do so.

pros: One of the benefits of working at UMaine is the option of taking classes and pursuing a degree, tuition free.
cons: It is hit or miss whether you land in a department where your contributions will be welcomed and valued, and opportunities for professional development and promotion offered.

review_title: I stepped in to a job that was fast moving and challenging.
pros: The community of people were very supportive to work with, leadership were hard working and set the bar. The health insurance was one of the best benefits. Training was a great part of the job.
cons: Work volume was very busy.

job_title: Campus Recreation Manager in Orono, ME
pros: Flexible hours, great pay, great working environment, heavy vetting on staff, great Graduate Assistant
cons: The general public can be very annoying, sometimes must clean human waste up, dealing with the occasional person on drugs

pros: This is a great place to work and there is some mobility for those that work hard and put the time in.
cons: The system is very large and it can be hard to connect with students individually. There are at times cuts due to state legislature.

pros: Stipend wasn't bad (if you live small),  spend my master's doing this, and was relatively enjoyable way to get your master's completed while getting bills paid
cons: Work load can vary from semester to semester depending on who you TA for.

pros:
Flexible Hours
Beautiful Campus 
Great Direct Supervisors
cons:
Older Buildings
Poor Funding
Department pays as little as possible

review_title: My experience at the University of Maine at Farmington has been refreshing and interesting.
pros: Flexibility, Excellent Benefits, Conveniences, Teamwork, Support, Great Vacation and Sick Leave Package, Retirement Investment
cons: Distance to Travel, Hours of Operation, Lack of Communication, Lack of Training

review_title: Quality undergraduate education and research experience
pros: Open, friendly environment with easy access to on-site and locally-available facilities. Faculty promote a collaborative environment.
cons: Geographically isolated from other major institutions.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Invigorating to be with students excited to know what their fields are like in the real world
cons: Scheduling of seminars is often juggled based on current need

review_title: Great place to work and learn
pros: Great employee culture, open learning and training environment for all employees, and great benefits.
cons: It takes a lot to get something changed or updated due to 'the way we've always done it' mentality.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Orono, ME
pros: Small school feel where professors are willing to help you if you are willing to put in the effort.
cons: Not as many amenities or opportunities as a big city school. Departments don't have much money. Cold.

pros: benefits, working in education, flexibility, ability to be creative, educational opportunities
cons: politics, bad overall moral due to upper management secrets about things that aren't important, yet create mistrust among staff, poor pay

review_title: Not terrible, not a lot of pay, but plenty of time to do homework.
pros: Opportunity to get done homework, fair work environment.
cons: Low wages, lots of down time.

review_title: My time teaching Upward Bound at UMaine was an important part of my professional development.
pros: Excellent people - positive work environment.
cons: Not a lot of training.

pros:
-flexible work hours
-small workload
-teaching others is a good chance to review your own understanding of a topic.
cons: -sometimes, I have to TA for a class that I never took before.

review_title: Good experience for engineers. So many interesting projects
pros: the staff are very friendly and are willing to help you in any way
cons: very small though. Can hardly expand contacts

pros: The University of Maine system was very organized, and I enjoyed the short amount of time I worked there.
cons: No complaints, good place to work.

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Orono, ME
pros: Great application of skills and knowledge; paid regardless of appointment.
cons: College students do not always show up to appointments.

job_title: Research Assistant in Presque Isle, ME
pros: Was able to perform research and maintain a flexible schedule.  This was seasonal employment.
cons: Pays close to minimum wage.

pros: Abet certified, and Lots of parties.
cons: Located at the center of Hoth

pros: University of Maine in Orono is a great place to work and study
cons: Could use more career opportunties

review_title: Lack of work ethic and responsibility in facilities management
pros: The benefits are decent, work can be very interesting.
cons: Poor workmanship, administrative red tape, unorganized and wastefulness

review_title: Willing to train in tasks you are unfamiliar with.
pros: I do not have to work weekends. Pay is competitive.
cons: Not enough time to train.

pros: Generally well-run and responsive; also provides good online accessibility
cons: Too much middle management and scattered administration

pros:
Good work atmosphere
Friendly co-workers and administration
cons:
Not much opportunity for career growth
Poor management, or lack there of

pros: Flexible hours, great staff, wonderful environment
cons: Lots of work! Great if you're up to the task.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bangor, ME
pros: Enough money to lead a student life
cons: Same amount for both Masters and PhD candidates

pros: Direct boss was a joy to work for
cons: Restructuring and retitling is a constant. Salary is sub-par

pros: Flexibility, decent salary, great benefits
cons: Not much room for advancement

pros: Benefits are very generous and flexible
cons: Lack of respect by management for workers. Political environment is toxic.

job_title: IT Help Desk in Portland, ME
pros: Very flexible work and very understanding managers.
cons: Too many calls on-peak hours

pros: Good atmosphere, interesting projects and work
cons: nothing much except the weather

pros: Research Opportunities; Dedicated and accomplished peers
cons: Lack of adequate state support

pros: Great benefits & very diverse
cons: sometimes there wasn't good communication with staffing

pros: easy fun working with students
